content.question:
<math alttext="H C l aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive one charge aqueous plus C l with a negative one charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
In <math alttext="1.0 molar H C l aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="H C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is nearly 100 percent dissociated, as represented by the equation above. Which of the following best helps to explain why, in <math alttext="0.01 molar H C N aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.01</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HCN</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, less than 1 percent of <math alttext="H C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is dissociated?

choices.label: The <math alttext="C N with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>CN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ion is not very soluble in water, and a solid precipitate would form if more of the <math alttext="H C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> dissociated.

Compared to the <math alttext="H C l aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> solution, the concentration of the <math alttext="H C N aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> solution is much too dilute to achieve 100 percent dissociation.

The equilibrium constant for the dissociation of <math alttext="H C N aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is much smaller than that for the dissociation of <math alttext="H C l aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="H C N aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with water to form a basic solution, and the high concentration of <math alttext="O H with a negative one charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> interferes with the dissociation process.

content.answer: The equilibrium constant for the dissociation of <math alttext="H C N aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is much smaller than that for the dissociation of <math alttext="H C l aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 6.D: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using chemical principles or laws, or using mathematical justification.
